com.lonepulse.robozombie.response
Class ResponseProcessorChain

java.lang.Object
  com.lonepulse.robozombie.processor.AbstractProcessorChain<Object,com.lonepulse.robozombie.response.ResponseProcessorException>
      com.lonepulse.robozombie.response.ResponseProcessorChain
All Implemented Interfaces:
Processor<Object,com.lonepulse.robozombie.response.ResponseProcessorException>
public final class ResponseProcessorChain
extends AbstractProcessorChain<Object,com.lonepulse.robozombie.response.ResponseProcessorException>

This is a concrete implementation of AbstractProcessorChain which creates a sequentially executed series of AbstractResponseProcessors responsible for handling the HttpResponse of an endpoint request invocation.

This chain consists of the AbstractResponseProcessors listed below in the given order:

  1. HeaderProcessor - retrieves the response headers and makes them available
  2. EntityProcessor - deserializes and returns the content of the response body

Note that this processor-chain may or may not return the deserialized response entity depending on the availability of response content.

Note that a chain-wide failure is NOT recoverable. All failures are of type ResponseProcessorException which may be thrown from any arbitrary ProcessorChainLink. Any changes made on the arguments to the chain are NOT rolled back.

Since:
1.3.0

Version:
1.1.0

Author:
Lahiru Sahan Jayasinghe

  1. HeaderProcessor - retrieves the response headers and makes them available
  2. EntityProcessor - deserializes and returns the content of the response body

Method Detail

onInitiate

protected Object onInitiate(ProcessorChainLink<Object,com.lonepulse.robozombie.response.ResponseProcessorException> root,
                            Object... args)

Executed for the root link which runs the HeaderProcessor. Takes the argument array which was provided in AbstractProcessorChain.run(Object...) and invokes the root link, i.e. the HeaderProcessor and returns the deserialized response content passed down from the successive processor.

See AbstractResponseProcessor.

This callback is invoked for the root ProcessorChainLink in this chain. It can be used to implement any pre-chain processing and should execute the root link which produces the first RESULT.

Specified by:
onInitiate in class AbstractProcessorChain<Object,com.lonepulse.robozombie.response.ResponseProcessorException>
Parameters:
root - the first ProcessorChainLink which produces the initial RESULT

args - the arguments which are passed along to each successive ProcessorChainLink

Returns:
the RESULT which is produced by executing the first ProcessorChainLink

onTraverse

protected Object onTraverse(Object result,
                            ProcessorChainLink<Object,com.lonepulse.robozombie.response.ResponseProcessorException> successor,
                            Object... args)

Executed for each "link-crossing" from the root HeaderProcessor onwards. Takes the successor and invokes it with the argument array which was provided in AbstractProcessorChain.run(Object...) and returns the deserialized response content (if any).

See AbstractResponseProcessor.

This callback is invoked when the execution of the chain progresses from the current link to the next; i.e. a ProcessorChainLink successor is available. All implementations are expected to handle the process of crossing links by using the RESULT of the previous link's execution and invoking the successor as they see fit. The RESULT of the current link's execution should be returned so that it is passed along to the next successor.

Note that failures of recoverable Processors should be explicitly handled and recovered from where possible

As an example, consider a Processor with a result type of Void. This signifies that the Processor implementation does not return a result and its execution is based solely on the input to the processor chain. In such situations the RESULT should be ignored original argument array should be passed to the successor.

Consider another example where you require a premature termination of the chain for the current invocation context. An additional boolean flag could be added to a copy of the argument array which would be passed on to the successor. The implementation of onTraverse() and onTerminate should check the existence of this additional parameter and skip invocation of the successor and the terminal link respectively.

Although the Processor wrapped in the ProcessorChainLink may choose to skip the processing, this decision is limited to the input it receives and it's unaware of the implementation details of the chain in which it resides. Hence this decision can only be made from a context which has a holistic view of the AbstractProcessorChain.

Specified by:
onTraverse in class AbstractProcessorChain<Object,com.lonepulse.robozombie.response.ResponseProcessorException>
Parameters:
result - the result from the execution of the current ProcessorChainLink which should be passed on to the successor link in this iteration of onTraverse()

successor - the next ProcessorChainLink which should be executed with the RESULT of the current link and the subsequent RESULT of this successor should be returned in turn

args - the arguments which are passed along to each successive ProcessorChainLink

Returns:
the RESULT which was produced by executing the successor ProcessorChainLink

onTerminate

protected void onTerminate(Object result,
                           Object... args)

No terminal conditions are performed.

See AbstractResponseProcessor.

This callback is invoked by the last link in the chain. It can be used for post-chain processing before allowing the chain to exit with the final RESULT.

Specified by:
onTerminate in class AbstractProcessorChain<Object,com.lonepulse.robozombie.response.ResponseProcessorException>
Parameters:
result - the result from the execution of the final ProcessorChainLink

args - the arguments which were passed down from the preceding ProcessorChainLink
